loans.name: Touma

texts.en:
Touma J. is 28 years old and married with 2 children who both go to school. Her husband is a driver, and she is currently in the business of designing and selling bedsheets. Touma is requesting a loan to purchase more materials for this business and hopes to use her extra profits to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Materials for making and selling bedsheets

loans.name: Celfora

texts.en:
Celfora S. is from the village of Lodiong Tambulig ZDS. She is 26 years old. Celfora is married and has one infant child. Celfora owns & operates a  general store that sells daily use products such as shampoo, toothpaste, junk foods, canned goods, etc., in the local community. Celfora has been in business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month, equivalent to about $65 US.

In 2009, Celfora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celfora has successfully repaid her first loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Celfora is requesting a second loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guilerma F. is a 49-year-old resident of Santa Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She has a farm and rice is her main crop. The income she makes from her farm helps to buy her family an adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs. The Income also has helped to pay for the daily expenses in their home.

She would like to expand her business, but she need additional capital. She would like to request a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies for her business.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Ayya

texts.en:
Ayya S. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts paste in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell. Ayya is 35 years old and she is widowed. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a groundnut store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Erika Luzmila

texts.es:
Erika A. de 27 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y si cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, su esposo tiene un local en donde vende cilindros de gas no tienen hijos. 

Erika comenzó dando sus servicios como maquilladora visitando a sus clientes en sus domicilios, poco a poco comenzó a tener ingresos suficientes para poner un pequeño gabinete de belleza. 

Ahora ella trabaja todos los días desde las 12h00 hasta las 22h00, haciendo cortes de cabello, tinturados, secados etc. Una de las complicaciones que tiene es atender el negocio en el estado de embarazada.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar tintes, sacadoras, silla para agrandar el negocio. En el futuro tener ayudantes y poner una sucursal del gabinete de belleza.
texts.en:
Erika A. is 27 years old and lives in a suburban area in Paraiso de Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement and she has all the basics; her husband has a stand where he sells gas cilinders and they are expecting their first child. Erika started her business as a makeup artist by visiting her clients in their homes, and soon she had enough clients to open her own beauty salon. She now works every day from 12pm until 10pm, giving haircuts, dying and styling hair. Her only difficulty at the moment is that she's pregnant and needs to keep working. With the loan she wishes to buy more dye, hair driers, chairs and other equipment to expand her business. She hopes to hire people to help her out in the future and open another branch of her salon.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of equipment for hair salon

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Ky K. is 35 years old and is married. He resides with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has a five-year-old child. He is employed at a cigarette company in the city, earning approximately 4 USD in revenue per day. He has been with this company since 2006. His wife sells vegetables and fruits at a local market, and she is able to earn a gross income of 50 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Their standard of living has improved since they started these businesses. They would now like a loan in order to expand their businesses. K. is requesting a loan of 300 USD to purchase more vegetables and fruits for his wife to sell at the market. This is his first loan from CREDIT and partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: Buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Planting rice and vegetable is the main activity of Mrs. P.’s daily routine. She has been farming her crop on her medium farmland for nine years. From her business, she is able to generate over $5 each day to help cover her family's expenses. P. has a life partner in her husband who assists her in growing crops. The couple has a school-aged kid who is dependent on their income. P. wants to earn extra profit and is asking for a loan as capital to book a neighbor’s plantation where the cashews grow. She will harvest and sell these.

loans.use: To book a neighbor’s plantation

loans.name: Zerifa

texts.en:
Zerifa Lucy is in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. She is 22 years old and married to a farm worker. They have two children who go to school. With the extra profits her loan will make possible, she hopes to be able to build a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Olayemi

texts.en:
Olayemi is 35 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. Olayemi sells groceries, such as milk, sugar and toothpaste, and has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. Olayemi is a hardworking woman who is determined to pull her business and family out of poverty. She is a client of Kiva partner, LAPO, and is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

About LAPO
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Sandra Maria

texts.es: Sandra Maria es casada con el Sr. Julio Castilla con quien tiene 6 hijos, el mayor tiene 28 años y el menor 12. Todos habitan en la Comarca La Palma del municipio de Tecolostote.  Es comerciante de leche la que ademas procesa y obtiene crema, queso y cuajadas las que vende a las personas de su comunidad. Cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien asume los gastos del hogar.  Esta solicitando su primer credito con el objetivo de mejorar su vivienda, reparando una pared que se encuentra en mal estado, y de esta manera brindar a su familia mayor seguridad.  El mayor sueño de Sandra es poder tener una vivienda digna con las condiciones basicas para que su familia se sienta comoda.
texts.en:
Sandra Maria is married to Julio Castilla; they have 6 children ranging from 28 to 12 years of age. They all live in La Palma, Tecolostote municipality. She is a milk merchant but also produces cream, cheese and cuajadas (a type of white cheese) for sale to her neighbors. Her husband helps out by providing for household expenses. She is asking for her first loan for home improvements; she wants to repair a wall that is damaged so that her family can have better security. Sandra’s greatest wish is to have a home that is proper with basic conditions for her family to feel comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To erect a wall.

loans.name: Wellingtone

texts.en:
Wellingtone B. O. M. is fifty-two years old. His wife is a farmer and they live in Kakamega where they run their business.

Wellingtone engages in transport services and serves the people of Kakamega. He has been in this business for the last ten years and he says the business gives him income to take care of his family.

Wellingtone says the business is good and the only major challenge is that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his and so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. He, however, works very hard to ensure that his business is doing well.

Wellingtone is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to spray-paint his vehicle. He hopes to buy more vehicles in the future to expand his business. He also has dreams of giving his children a quality education. He is hardworking, ambitious and patient.

loans.use: To spray-paint his vehicle

loans.name: Leatitie

texts.en:
Leatitie is 26 years old and is married with one child who is three years old. Leatitie is the only one in her family who has a business. She owns a small business selling various products such as cosmetic products, juice, water, and so on. This business is profitable in the region where it is located and this is her 4th successful year in operation.

Leatitie is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more drinks to sell. With this loan she will be able to satisfy the demands of her customers and, with this satisfaction, she hopes to earn more money from the additional products in her shop. With the extra money, Leatitie will be able to save money for the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more drinks to sell

loans.name: Adama Oumar

texts.fr: Adama Oumar D. est une femme de 41 ans, elle mariée sans enfants mais tutrice de 7 enfants qui lui sont confiés par des parents et des proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SINTIHIANG AÏDARA depuis 2006 et a 7 fois de suite reçu de crédit qu’elle a toujours bien géré et remboursé à temps. Elle est vendeuse de tissus et son nouveau crédit lui permettra à mieux développer son activité. Les bénéfices réalisés à partir de sa vente lui permettent de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Adama Oumar D., 41, is married without biological children, but is the guardian of seven children who have been confided to her by their parents or by other kinfolks. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of SINTIHIANG AÏDARA since 2006 and has received seven consecutive loans which she put to good use and reimbursed in a timely manner. She sells cloth, and her new loan will allow her to expand her business. The profit from her sales will permit her to help improve living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolster her cloth business

loans.name: Benita Gregoria

texts.es: Benita es de 65 años de edad, es casada, tiene tres hijos un varón y dos mujeres, se dedica a la comercialización de ropa para niño, en la actividad tiene aproximadamente 10 años de experiencia, solicita su segundo crédito para incrementar su capital en mercadería y surtir mejor su venta, el anterior crédito lo pago sin problema de atraso,
texts.en:
Benita is 65 years old, she is married and has three children, a boy and two girls. She sells children's clothes, and she has been working in this field for about 10 years. She is requesting a second loan to buy more products and to better furnish her shop. She repaid her previous loan with no delay.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy core products.

loans.name: Abdurasul

texts.en: A. Abdurasul is a very hardworking and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. He is married and has five children. Abdurasul works in the central city market selling men’s national skullcaps and chapans (caftans). His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for 17 years. Abdurasul likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Abdurasul would like to ask for a loan of $2800 US to purchase new inventory. We believe Abdurasul‘s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of the growth of Abdurasul’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Shamshad

texts.en:
Shamshad is M. A.'s wife. They live in Shalimar, a district of the city of Lahore in Pakistan. Shalimar is famous for its fresh seasonal fruits. People can get the fresh fruit here without going anywhere else. 

Shamshad is a very caring lady. She is a grandmother and her grandchildren are very attached to her because of her caring and loving nature. Her husband has a dairy business. He has a buffalo at home and Shamshad helps him with milking. He sells the milk to various milk shops to earn income. Nowadays, his buffalo is producing insufficient milk which is affecting his sales. Therefore, Shamshad has applied for a loan for her husband’s dairy business. With the loan, he will buy another buffalo and expand his dairy business. 

Shamshad is a second year member of Asasah. In her first year, she showed good credit behavior and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To purchase a new buffalo for a dairy business

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A. sells cocoyam and plantain at Takoradi.  Nana has no educational background.  She is married with a child. Her husband sells wood. Nana has been selling cocoyam and plantain for some time now. She supports her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more cocoyam and plantain to sell and to distribute to the market women. She hopes to reinvest the profit she is going to get as a result of the loan into her business.

loans.use: To buy more cocoyam and plantain to sell .

loans.name: Ma. Mernaly

texts.en:
This is Ma. Mernaly G., 41, a resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to June G., a security guard, and mother to an elementary school-aged child. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college--a dream for most Filipino parents like Ma. Mernaly as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Ma. Mernaly operates a rug-making business and at the same time is a fabric dealer. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm-sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Ma. Mernally dreams of being able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Busheregyenyi Bakyara Kwebeishaho, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
M. Bennon of Busheregyenyi Bakyara Kwebeishaho group in Bushenyi is a fledgling agro-sales business trend setter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other people in his home area of Karehe Bushenyi. He has earned his living with a produce-sales business over a time frame of more than 4 years. 

Many in his home area occupy themselves with self-destructive activities like drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana rather than working hard and shouldering their family responsibilities. With his hard work ethic, M. Bennon has managed to prosper and in a month he apparently makes 200,000 Ugandan shillings. With his monthly savings, he has managed to diversify his small business where he is involved in coffee, beans and bananas sales.

This has however not come the easy way as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as unpredictable weather patterns which may mean he has fewer supplies from farmers. He is looking forward to purchasing more beans and coffee to stock for resale. With this loan he hopes to be in a position to cater for his children’s education costs as he looks forward to improving his household income.

loans.use: purchase more stock for resale

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: A. Alice est mariée à HOUENOU Théophile, un peintre auto. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Alice vit avec sa famille depuis une douzaine d’année au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Alice n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Alice vend des tissus de différentes sortes (hitarget, bazins, etc.), des ustensiles de cuisine et des glacières par le système de distribution. De façon secondaire, Alice mène comme activité, la vente de fournitures scolaires. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin, que Alice achète ses produits. Alice exerce cette activité depuis onze ans et a déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Alice désire actuellement renforcer son activité et accroître son chiffre d’affaire ; raison pour laquelle Alice sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un sixième prêt.
texts.en:
Alice A. is married to Théophile HOUENOU, an automotive painter. The couple have three children, all of whom attend school. Alice and her family have lived for a dozen years in the Sènadé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Alice did not attend school. To support herself and her family, Alice sells different types of fabric (hitarget, bazin [damask], etc.), kitchenware and ice chests through the distribution system. Alice runs a secondary business selling school supplies. Alice buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin and also in Lomé, a neighboring country of Bénin. Alice has run this business for 11 years and has already received five loans from ALIDé that have been fully repaid. Alice is requesting a sixth loan from ALIDé because she now wants to bolster her business and increase her sales.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, kitchenware and school supplies.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro B. is from the village of Bungad. He is 46 years old. Pedro is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Pedro owns & operates a business catching and selling fresh-water fish at the market. Pedro has been engaged in his business for over 36 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pedro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Pedro is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Pedro from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret B. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has seven children, all of whom attend school.  Margaret has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Margaret sells her products door-to-door.   Margaret has requested a loan for 70,0000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of charcoal.     She also generates additional income with a food stall.  Margaret's main business challenges are transportation and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and to buy a plot of land.   Margaret lives in a home, which she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food for her family.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Virginia Gabriela

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Charapoto se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Virgen De Lourdes. Esta localidad se conoce por su cultura tradicional y además por estar a pocos minutos de dos de las  mejores playas de la provincia como son San Jacinto y San Clemente.

La señora Virginia es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Virgen de Lourdes y está muy a gusto en el ya que aquí ha encontrado mucha ayuda para ella y su negocio. Se desempeña como fiscal de pagos del Banco. Ella tiene 30 años de edad mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha tenido tres hijos de 11- 10 y 6 años, todos ellos están en la escuela. Su marido es ebanista. Ella estudia en la Universidad Técnica De Manabí Ing. Comercial.

Ella además de ser una gran ama de casa también tiene un comedor en su casa, trabaja los viernes, sabados y domingos desde las 7am hasta las 19h00, prepara muchos platos para complacer a sus clientes y los domingos prepara salchichas y caldo de manguera ya que este es un plato típico muy solicitado por sus clientes.

Este crédito es para productos para la preparación de la comida y para comprar unas sillas y mesas para dar a sus clientes una mejor atención. Su sueño  terminar sus estudios en Ing. Comercial.
texts.en:
In the city of Charapoto, there is a gathering every two weeks for the communal bank "Banco Comunal Virgen De Lourdes."  The city is known for its traditional culture and also for being just a few minutes away from two of the best beaches in the province, San Jacinto and San Clemente.

Señora Virginia is the founding member of the communal bank "Banco Comunal Virgen de Lourdes."  She is very happy with the bank because it has given both her and her business a lot of help.  She is the bank's payment auditor.  She is 30 years old and lives with her partner.  Together they have three children, who are 11, 10 and 6 years old.  All of her children attend school.  Her husband is a cabinet baker.  Señora Virginia is studying Commercial Engineering at La Universidad Técnica De Manabí (Manabí's Technical University).

In addition, Señora Virginia is a great housewife and has an eatery in her home  She works on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 7am until 7pm preparing many dishes to satisfy her customers.  On Sundays she makes sausages and "caldo de manguera" (sausage soup), since those are typical foods that her customers often request.

This loan is intended for the purchase of the products needed to prepare the food and to purchase some chairs and tables to better serve her customers.  Señora Virginia's dream is to complete her studies in Commercial Engineering.

loans.use: To purchase supplies, tables and chairs.

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco  y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Margarita; ella tiene 53 años de edad,casada y tiene 4hijos ; La socia tiene su negocio de kiosko el cual se encuentra ubicado en el instituto de Arco Iris de Cusco,a la vez se dedica a la crianza de animales como cuyes y gallinas en su casa para luego venderlo a sus amistades.  

La  socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de mas productos para su negocio como dulces,galletas,caramelos,tortas,entre otros .

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the Hatun Soncco Community Bank located in the Cuzco district of Cuzco. Mrs. Margarita is 53 years old, married, and has four children. She has a kiosk in the Rainbow Institute of Cuzco and also works at home raising animals such as guinea pigs and chickens that she later sells to her friends.

She is asking for a loan to buy more products for her business, like candy, cookies, caramels, sandwiches, and others. She is thankful for all the people who help make her dream come true through these means and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Candy, cookies, caramels, sandwiches, etc.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal Nacer, tiene 47 años y 2 hijos.
Margarita se dedica a la confección de faldas, fustes, inaguas. Se dedica a la confección desde muy joven, comenzó confeccionándose ella misma sus prendas de las faldas de su mama, desataba las costuras y las adecuaba a su gusto, poco a poco fue comprando sus cosas necesarias para confeccionar, ahora los trabajos que hace los distribuye en los puestos de mercado y a atiende los contratos que le hacen. El prestamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de telas, hilos, blondas.
A Margarita le gusta las reuniones de sy Banco comunal porque le dan préstamos y puede ahorrar, cuando se reúne con sus compañeras de banco aprenden mucho de las capacitaciones que reciben de su promotora.
Su sueño es que sus hijos sean profesionales y que tengan su negocio propio.
texts.en:
Margarita, 47, is a member of the “Nacer” (To Be Born) communal bank.  She has two children.  

Margarita manufactures skirts, underskirts, traditional blouses.  She has been a dressmaker since very young; she started out making her own clothes out of her mother’s skirts.  She’d undo the stitches and remake them to her liking.  She gradually bought the dressmaking supplies she needed.  Now, she sells her items in stands in the market and fills orders she gets.  The loan will be used to buy fabric, thread and lace trim.

Margarita enjoys the meetings of her communal bank because she gets loans and can have savings.  When she gets together with her fellow bank members she learns a lot at the training sessions they get from their advisor.

Her dream is that her children become professionals and have businesses of their own.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread and lace trim.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa K., who sells both cooked and raw rice in Takoradi, assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of rice to cook for sale and to sell as raw rice. She anticipates using the new profits from her business to save towards the education of her children.

At the time this photo was taken, Adwoa had not yet cooked the rice for her afternoon customers.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice to cook for sale and to sell as raw rice.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita G. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 43 years old and married, with 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for more than 8 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria D. is from the village of Mainit, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Maria is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, detergents, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Maria is requesting a new loan of 21000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Maria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta V. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Philippines. She is 39 years old. Violeta is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Violeta owns and operates a business venture raising livestock; she also sells spare motorcycle parts in her local community. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for Violeta's business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Violeta has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP every four months. Additionally, she usually earns a minimum of 2000 PHP per month selling spare motorcycle parts.

In 2006, Violeta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Violeta has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI of 15000 PHP, which was used to purchase breeding livestock. Violeta is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Violeta's 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Ramel

texts.en:
Ramel E. is from the village of Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 27 years old. Ramel is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Ramel owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing recycling services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling plastics & other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Ramel has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ramel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Ramel is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ramel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell

location.town: Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Suk

texts.en: Suk P. is a 49-year-old married man who currently lives in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. He is a policeman who works in the Ministry of National Police. He started his job more than a year ago. Suk P. is blessed with four single kids: two of them are still enrolled in school while the remaining two are employed in different jobs. His wife works as a sewing worker at the garment factory. Suk P. always uses his motor to ride to his job location. Unfortunately, his motorbike often has broken down during use. Because of that, Suk P. has decided to seek a loan from Kiva, which he will use to change the broken motorcycle. He hopes to use the rest of the funds to repair his old house.

loans.use: To change a broken motorcycle and repair his old house

loans.name: Mechelle

texts.en:
Mechelle V. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Mechelle is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mechelle owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling ready to wear clothing and blankets, and she also sells beauty products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community. She sells silver-plated jewelry as well. Mechelle has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mechelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Mechelle is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts, blouses and pillow cases. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts, blouses and pillow cases

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.  Amparo requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fishing gear and equipment.

Amparo has been in this business for 35 years now, and also earns additional income from buying and selling gasoline.  In the future, Amparo would like to do some improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: To make a living, Esi A. sells both fish and palm kernel oil at her village, Mfuom, which is near Abura town in the Central Region. She has been selling both items for the past two years to supplement the household income. She is married to a trader. Her goal is to expand her businesses and with her loan, she will purchase larger quantities of both items to increase her sales. Her intention is to reinvest the earnings back into both businesses for further growth.

loans.use: To purchase fish and palm kernel oil

loans.name: Valeria

texts.es: La señora Valeria   es una clienta antigua de la institución y  ha mostrando buena voluntad de pago y un trato amable y Cortez en la evaluación que se le hizo,  La clienta realiza la venta de edredones y frazadas los días sábados y domingos en la populosa zona de la 16 de julio de el alto-Bolivia. Empieza su labor al rededor de las 17:00 entregando estos productos a crédito a los locales de fiestas que por esta zona abundan  y al siguiente día recoge el pago de estas ventas realizadas, de lunes a viernes ella trabaja como costurera de edredones para una microempresa privada al rededor de 5 años, por lo cual la señora Valeria cuenta con la experiencia para emprender esta nueva actividad, el conyugue es empleado en una empresa de embutidos por lo cual aporta al ingreso familiar. el dinero del  credito es para la compra de tela ya que la Señora Valeria desea confeccionar edredones para poder vender, Es sacrificado el esfuerzo que ellos realizan para tener mejores condiciones de vida,  el mayor sueño de la familia es llegar a tener un  patrimonio estable y que sus hijos lleguen a tener una carrera profesional, por lo que se esfuerzan en lograrlo día a día.
texts.en:
Valeria is a longstanding client of the institution and has shown good willingness to pay and kind and courteous behavior during the evaluation that was done on her.

She sells comforter and blankets on Saturdays and Sundays in the heavily populated 16 de Julio zone of El Alto, Bolivia.  She starts work around 5pm.  She delivers her products on credit to party centers that are common in this area and collects payment the next day for completed sales.

From Monday through Friday she works sewing comforters for a private micro firm; she’s been doing this for about 5 years.  Because of this, Valeria has the necessary experience to start this new activity.  Her spouse is employed at a cured meats firm so he contributes to family income.

The loan money will be used to buy fabric because Valeria wants to make comforters to sell.  The efforts they put into having better living conditions is constant.  The family’s greatest wish is to have a stable patrimony so that their children can have professional careers.  They struggle daily to attain this end.

loans.use: to buy fabric and fleece to make comforters.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel is now 25 years old and married with two infant children. Isabel is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns approximately PHP 4,000 per month. 

Isabel is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 to pay laborers to increase their crop yields. Isabel has been growing root crops for almost three years.

In the future, Isabel hopes to strengthen their source of income so that they can support the needs of their family, especially the education of their children. She believes that with the continuous financial support of the Kiva lenders she can start another kind of business.

loans.use: To pay for laborers to work on her farm

loans.name: C4712 Tuzamukane B Group

texts.en:
Emmailine is 43 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 5 and 15. Her business is well-organized. Emmailine is the team leader of this group called "Tuzamuke B", which is well known in the business of selling clothes. Their business hours are from 7 am until 7 pm every day.

Emmailine and her team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their business by buying more clothes to sell. They will reinvest the profits in their business and save for their future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Filomena Roxana

texts.es: La señora Filomena se dedica a la venta de artículos de temporada en esta época vende ropa como chompas y blusas, comenzó con esta actividad desde joven junto a su amiga ahora venden estos productos en la ceja de el alto y en ferias zonales, poco a poco logro reunir un capital considerable, donde los ingresos que le genera esta actividad le ayuda con los gastos familiares, su esposo es albañil y ambos viven con sus hijos en casa de su suegra. Es la primera vez que solicitan crédito en una institución financiera. Con mucho esfuerzo lograron construir parte de su domicilio,  ahora solicitan el crédito para terminar la construcción de dos cuartos más y dar mayor comodidad a sus hijos. Se esfuerzan para brindar a sus hijos un mejor futuro.
texts.en: Mrs. Filomena sells seasonal goods.  This time of year she sells sweaters and blouses.  She started working together with her friend when she was very young.  Now they sell these products in Ceja de El Alto and local fairs.  Little by little she was able to save a considerable amount of money.  Her earnings from this job help pay for family expenses.  Her husband is a masonry worker and both live in her mother-in-law’s house with their children.  This is the first time she has applied for a loan from a financial institution.  Through much effort they were able to build part of their house and now they are applying for the loan to finish building two more rooms to make their children more comfortable.  They try hard to offer their children a better future.

loans.use: BUY BUILDING MATERIALS TO FINISH TWO BEDROOMS

loans.name: Maria Gloria

texts.en: Maria Gloria is a mother of four and lives in the San Lorenzo region of Honduras. For the last three years she has made a living by selling basic foodstuffs and household products out of her home. She is requesting a loan of Lps.10,000 to purchase merchandise.

loans.use: to purchase meats, cheeses, fruits, vegetables, snacks, milk, soft drinks, basic grains, salt, butter, cooking oil, basic household cleaning products, and personal hygiene products.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, age 59 is married to James who is an accountant. She owns a boutique and also runs a tailoring business which has been in operation for eighteen years.The business earns her a monthly income of KES.37,000.

This is her first loan term with KADET LTD.She will use the funds to buy a machine for embroidery. Monica intends to use the anticipated profits to finish building her rental houses and hopes to export her embroidery materials to southern Sudan in the future.

loans.use: To buy a machine for embroidery

loans.name: Melissa Marie Fabiola

texts.es:
Melissa tiene 26 años de edad, está cursando la carrera de Licenciatura en Psicología. Se encuentra cursando actualmente el segundo año de la carrera. Comenta que quienes la ayudan en el gasto de sus estudios son sus padres.
Su madre es ama de casa y su padre es docente. Melissa, con mucho esfuerzo está logrando cubrir los gastos de su Universidad, como ser la matricula, materiales didácticos y otros. Su sueño es terminar su carrera y convertirse en una buena profesional, también sueña con poder asistir a charlas y seminarios internacionales donde podrá ampliar el conocimiento obtenido en la universidad. 
Ella solicita el crédito para cubrir los gastos de su universidad, como ser cuotas y demás. Ella agradece la oportunidad que le da la Fundación ya que sabe que le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
Melissa is 26 years old and is working toward her Bachelor’s degree in Psychology.  She is currently in the second year of the course work.  She comments that her parents are the ones helping her with school expenses.

Her mother is a housewife and her father’s a Teacher.  Through much effort, Melissa is paying such costs in her major as registration fees, school supplies and others.  Her dream is to complete the career and become a good professional.  She also dreams with being able to attend international seminars where she will be able to expand on what she’s learned at university.

She is asking for the loan to cover costs, like tuition payments and others, at the university.  She is grateful for the opportunity the Fundación is giving her.

loans.use: Pago de las cuotas de la Universidad

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 69 years old and married to Veronicah. The couple has three children who all go to school. For the past 13 years, Samuel has been a farmer in Ndunyu Njeru town. 

Samuel was introduced to KADET by a staff field officer and this will be his third loan. He is requesting a loan to buy seed and fertilizer. In future, Samuel hopes to become a leading farmer in his area.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria nació en la ciudad de Curahuasi del departamento de Apurímac (Perú) y tiene 39 años de edad. Ella está casada y fruto de esta unión tiene cuatro hijos y viven en la ciudad del Cusco. Ella tiene un puesto de venta de golosinas de forma ambulatoria osea en la calle. Ya son dos años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que en su trabajo. En esta oportunidad Gregoria desea comprar golosinas. El sueño de la Socia es comprarse una casa pues vive en una casa en alquiler.  
    
El Banco Comunal “El Molinito II” se reúne cada treinta en la ciudad del Cusco (Perú).  Cusco es conocido por ser una zona muy turística, comercial, por su fiesta tradicional del Inti Raymi y porque se encuentra una de las siete maravillas del mundo “Machupicchu”.
texts.en:
Gregoria was born in the town of Curahuasi, in Apurímac department (Peru).  She is 39 years old, married, and has four children.  They live in the city of Cusco.

Gregoria has a candy stall which is located in the street.  She has been in business for two years and is doing very well thanks to the effort that she puts into her work.  On this occasion, Gregoria needs a loan to buy candies.  Her dream is to buy her own home as she lives in a rental house.

The 'El Molinito II' community bank meets every month in the city of Cusco (Peru).  Cusco is a very touristy and commercial area.  It is known for its 'Inti Raymi' traditional fiesta and because it is home to one of the seven wonders of the world (Machupicchu).

loans.use: to buy candies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 37 years old and married with one child.

Gloria works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Gloria has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for six years and also earns an income from food vending.

Gloria aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 30 years old, married and has three children.  He runs a cereals shop to earn a living.  He has been in the business for three years. Alongside his cereals shop, he sells electric items such as electric cables so as to supplement his income.  Previously, he used to sell vegetables.

Daniel has improved his business through the trainings conducted by Faulu Kenya on business management. He needs a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy beans, maize and rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy beans, maize and rice to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a hardworking businesswoman aged 31. She is married and blessed with three children. For the last ten years, she has been operating a tailoring business to make a living. She also does farming to supplement her income. In the next 5 years, she wants to open and run a boutique. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy a sewing machine.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Elva

texts.es:
Elva es socia del Banco Comunal San Benito, tiene 32 años y es socia de FINCA Peru desde hace 3 años. 
Elva se dedica a la ventas de cereales en las ferias, y tiene 2 moto taxis, en el tiempo que esta en FINCA Peru ha podido ver todo lo que ha progresado económicamente y como persona gracias a las capacitaciones que ha recibido en su Banco Comunal, con su mamá empezaron el negocio, ahora ella ya tiene su propio capital.
Con el préstamo que esta solicitando ella comprará cereales para llevar a las ferias, su meta es poder terminar su carrera.
texts.en:
Elva is a member of the San Benito communal bank.  She is 32 years old, and she has been a member of FINCA for three years.

Elva sells grains at the fairs, and she has two “moto taxis” (three wheeled motorized vehicles).  In the time that she has been with FINCA Peru she has been able to see all of the progress she has made financially and as a person.  This is thanks to the trainings she has received in her communal bank.

Elva and her mother started the business, and now she has her own capital.

She will use the requested loan to buy grains to take to the fairs.  Her goal is to be able to finish her studies.

loans.use: to buy grains wholesale.

loans.name: Zineth

texts.en:
Zineth is 28 years old.  She is married and has 1 child. 

Zineth runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 3 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap and other miscellaneous items. Zineth has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

In the future, Zineth would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Maria Erica

texts.es:
La  señora María Erica  es de una Ribera muy bonita ella es casada con el señor Juvenal y con quien  procreo  seis hijos que  aun están a su responsabilidad.

     Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo  en fundación realidad y es para invertirlo en  la compra  ingredientes como  son: azúcar, queso, aceite, harina, royal, entre otros para la elaboración de panes, en donde lleva elaborando  cuatro años y le va bien ya que a logrado mejorar sus ingresos con su pequeña actividad.

    Quien el  motivo a dedicarse a esta actividad fue su mama ya que  desde muy pequeña inicio con apoyarla a vender pero cuando se caso dejo de elaborarlo y hace unos años comenzó de nuevo y le va bien.

   Lo que más desea es que con esta pequeña actividad ella pueda seguir adelante, trabajando con la elaboración de panes ahorrar para apoyar a sus hijos en la escuela.
texts.en:
María Érica is from a pretty riverside community. She is married to Juvenal, with whom she has six children that are still under their responsibility.
This is the first time she has requested a loan in the “Fundacion Realidad.” The loan is to invest in buying ingredients such as: sugar, cheese, oil, flour, baking powder, among others for the preparation of bread. She has been successfully making bread for 4 years, and she is improving her income with her small business.
Her mother motivated her to engage in this activity and she began to help her sell at a very young age, but stopped when she got married. A few ago, she began again, and she is doing well.
What she wants most is that with this small business she could continue forward and working with the production of bread to save to support her children in school.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make bread.

loans.name: Ngim

texts.en:
Ngim, age 54, lives in a village located about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.  

She is a widow with five sons and two daughters.  Six of her children are married, five live in separated homes and the other lives in the family's home.

Ngim sells pork in her local market.  

She is in the process of building a new house. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to finish construction.

loans.use: to finish her new house.

loans.name: Urozali

texts.ru: Урозали берет кредит для закупа несколько голов бычка и телят. Он хочет увеличить количество скота.
texts.en: Urozali is requesting a loan to purchase a few bulls and calves. He wants to increase the number of cattle.

loans.use: purchase a few bulls and calves.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is a farmer from Trinidad, Bohol. He tills his own land to plant rice crops. Jose sells his harvest to rice traders. He is able to provide for his family through farming. Jose works hard to improve his earnings and his family's living conditions.

Jose is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and other farm inputs. He hopes this loan will help him achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 48 years old, married and has 2 children. 

Marissa is in the agricultural business buying and selling livestock in the Philippines. Marissa requested a PHP 18000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional livestock to sell.

Marissa has been buying and selling livestock for 3 years now, and has borrowed 6 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Marissa would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock to sell

loans.name: Zamira

texts.ru: Замире 47 лет, замужем. После окончания пищевого техникума, Замира проработала 5 лет на заводе в отделе вино-водочных изделий, расположенном в городе Карабалта. Там она  познакомилась со своим будущим супругом и в 1991 году вышла замуж.  В настоящее время Замира - мать троих сыновей, старший сын Эркин  - ее главный помощник во всем, младшие учатся в школе.  5 лет назад, в поисках источника дохода для своей семьи, Замира начала свой бизнес в торговле продуктами питания, открыв небольшой магазин «БЕК», который расположен  в центральной части села Беловодское. Пройдя через многие испытания, Замира смогла развить свой бизнес с ежемесячным доходом в сумме 20,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду, Замира смогла приобрести автомашину для своей семьи. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Замира обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение  товарооборота и установку новых витрин. Доходы она планирует вложить  в дальнейшее расширение магазина.
texts.en: Zamira is 47 years old and married. After getting her degree in food services from a junior college, Zamira worked for five years at a wine and spirits distillery located in the town of Karabalta. This is where she met the man who would later become her husband. She got married in 1991. Now Zamira is the mother of three sons; the eldest son, Erkin, is her main helper in everything, and the younger sons are in schools. Five years ago, searching for a source of income for her family, Zamira launched her own business, opening a small grocery store named “Bek,” which is located in the central part of the village of Belovodskoe. After overcoming many challenges, Zamira was able to grow her business, which now brings a monthly income of 20,000 KGS. Thanks to her hard work, Zamira was able to  purchase a car for her family. In order to grow her business further, Zamira turned to “Bai Tushum and Partners” for a loan in the amount of 100,000 in order to increase her sales volume and install new display cases. She plans to reinvest her income in further development of her business.

loans.use: to broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Rosa Maribel

texts.es:
Rosa, nuevamente solicita otro préstamo para comprar un coche móvil y le facilita mejor andar los productos de mariscos como: conchas, pescado, camarones, de esa forma podrá trasladarse a varias zonas con el objetivo de vender sus productos a sus clientes.
Ella ha logrado mejorar con los prestamos anteriores que le ayudaron a siempre mantener el negocio estable, ella como su familia viven en mejores condiciones de vida que antes.
texts.en:
Rosa is requesting a new loan to purchase a vehicle which will make it easier to transport her shellfish products, such as conchs, fish, and shrimp.  In this way she will be able to transport them to different areas with the goal of selling her products to her customers.

She has seen improvements from her previous loans, which have helped her in keeping her business stable.  She and her family are living in better living conditions than they were previously.

loans.use: to purchase a vehicle for selling conchs, fish and shrimp.

loans.name: Sa Man

texts.en:
Sa Man, 31, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been involved in the agricultural business for over ten years, have extensive experience, and are successful in their career. They have four hectares of farmland for growing agricultural crops to generate income for the family. Additionally, her husband is an administrator in Preah Sdach district.

 In order to improve her agricultural business, Sa Man is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to pay for digging a well and purchasing a pump to pump water into her rice field in the dry season. By doing so, she would generate extra income in the dry season from her agricultural business to support her family. In the future, she would like to run a grocery store at home, build new house, and support her children to study until they get a Bachelor's degree.

loans.use: to pay for digging a well and purchase a pump to pump water into her rice field.

loans.name: Christ Vivant 2.1 Group

texts.en: Bernard is one of the members of the group Christ Vivant 2.1 and is the leader of a group consisting of four other micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Congo. Bernard has three children ranging in age from 3 to 11 years old. Bernard has a shop where he sells various merchandise to customers in his community, but he is constantly challenged by the frequent loss of power and instability of electricity in the city. One key to Bernard’s success is being able to locate and connect with suppliers outside of the city, which allows him to purchase his retail stock at lower prices than other retailers. In the future, Bernard plans to expand the type of products that he offers to clients and one day to save enough money to purchase a parcel of land for his children.

loans.use: This borrower will use this loan to replenish stock and merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine , 38 years old, married and have 3 children .Her husband is a tricycle driver transporting passenger to neighboring barangay and cities.

Josephine on the other hand wants to help her husband for their daily needs that is why she sell fish in the market.
Her previous loan was fully paid and she take another loan to increase her capital in fish selling.

Her future plans was to save money for their needs.

loans.use: To increase her capital in fish selling

location.town: Santo Nino, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
S. Dara is married and father of three children, all of them are go to school in Phnom Penh city. He is self-employed as a moto-taxi driver and makes around 15,000 Riel every day. His wife is running a very special business, as she sells Ants’ Eggs to a few traditional restaurants of the City. Ants’ Eggs are very scarce in Phnom Penh but S. Dara’s wife has good connections with collectors from the provinces and she can sell for 150,000 Riel ($37.5) daily with a margin of around 40%.

S. Dara already spent $900 of his personal savings on the roof and the walls of his new house but he needs an additional $500 to finish it. He will perform most of the building operations by himself and hopes to finish it very soon.

After building the house, S. Dara is considering resuming his career as a government officer he interrupted 7 years ago for familial obligations.

loans.use: Building a new house

loans.name: Evelyn Empesa

texts.en:
Evelyn is a single mother. Her husband passed away, leaving her 3 sons and 4 daughters. Two daughters are married. The rest of the children are dependent on the little income that Evelyn generates.

She operates a posho mill in addition to selling maize and cassava for milling. With the loan of $125, she plans to purchase additional stock of maize and cassava to sell. Her business is doing quite well and the additional investment is expected to improve her income.

With this additional income, Evelyn's welfare and that of her children will improve further, raising the overall status of the local community.

loans.use: To increase her stock of maize and cassava.

loans.name: Vy

texts.en: Miss Vy and her husband have 5 children between 13 and 1. They must support children going to school, and they must support their mother, who is old. The family doesn’t have any land, so they only earn money through their sales business. Hung, Miss Vy’s husband, buys coconuts from door to door and then sells them at the market. Vy also sells food for breakfast in the morning at the market. They borrowed a loan with no interest from the project, which has been important for them, as it increased their income by about $2.50/person/month. Average income is $12/person/month. Miss Vy has repaid a loan of $75, and now she asks to borrow a loan of $75 again.

loans.use: sells food for breakfast

loans.name: Yagub

texts.en:
Yagub is a 36 years old, married with 2 children.  He is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the occupied territory of Azerbaijan,  Fizuli region, living in the village of Akhmedallar.
Now he needs a loan of $725 to expand the area of his 4-year old store, where he sells foodstuffs, perfumery and other wares.

loans.use: to expand the area of his store

loans.name: Marcela Yamileth

texts.es:
For the last five years I have been making tortillas and selling them from door to door. My customers appreciate that I will either deliver to them or they can come to me. I am a single mother with three small children. I can support them now, but I want them to finish school.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Mi negoico es hacer totillas y venderlas ambulante en las calles. hace 5 anos que vendo tortillas. Tengo muy buenos clientes ya que voy personalmente adejarlas a sus hogares o ellos llegan donde yo estoy hubicada. Tengo 3 hijo pequeños los cuales estan en la escula y soy madre soltera. Con este negocio les doy una buena vida a mis hijos pero quiero que ellos terminen su escula.

loans.use: To buy milk, corn, lye, hand towels and cooking pans.

loans.name: Giovanna

texts.es:
Giovanna is loving father and mother to her three minor children. She is a very hardworking woman who has been able to succeed in spite of the many difficulties she has gone through. She currently works selling special bread products (made with milk and eggs), offering them while walking through the busiest streets of her city. In her free time, she works washing clothes in her small home, which allows her to earn an additional income to support her family. She lives in a rental room, and her greatest wish is to have her own bakery. She is aware that achieving that goal requires a large investment, and with this goal she has decided to save money and work even harder. For now, she wants to increase the amount of raw material she uses to make her products with the objective of generating larger income so that in little time her dreams can come true. Her request is for US $275, money she will invest entirely in her business and which she commits herself to repay within six months. Let’s make it possible for this noble mother to, through her work, make the dreams of her beloved children special.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteers.

Giovanna es padre y madre amorosa de sus tres hijos menores, es una mujer muy trabajadora que ha sabido sobresalir pese a las dificultades que tuvo que pasar; actualmente se dedica a vender panes especiales (con leche y huevo) en forma ambulatoria en las calles más concurridas de su ciudad y en sus horas libres se dedica a lavar ropa en su pequeña morada, este último oficio le genera un ingreso económico adicional para el sustento de su familia. Vive en una habitación alquilada y el anhelo más grande que tiene es poseer su propia panadería. Así mismo es consciente que para cumplir su objetivo requiere de una gran inversión, para lograr este propósito se ha propuesto ahorrar y esforzarse mucho más; por el momento desea aumentar la cantidad de materia prima que utiliza para la elaboración de sus productos a fin de generar mayores ingresos para que en poco tiempo haga realidad sus sueños. Su solicitud es por un monto de 275 dólares dinero que invertirá totalmente en su negocio, y se compromete hacer la devolución en un lapso de seis meses.Hagamos posibles que esta noble madre a través de su ocupación también pueda hacer especiales los sueños de sus queridos hijos.

loans.use: Buying materials to make bread

loans.name: Sera

texts.en:
Sera Ambigo M. is 30 years old.  She is married with three children and lives in the town of Mlolongo that sits along the Mombasa -Nairobi highway.

Sera graduated from one of the largest referral hospitals in East Africa, Kenyatta Medical Training Center, in 1999 and started operating her clinic and pharmacy shop in 2006.  She began the clinic with initial capital from savings she made while employed at the Kenyatta National Hospital as a doctor (USD $1470). 

Equipped with her savings and her technical skills, Sera approached her husband, who is also a qualified doctor, and together they started the clinic and pharmacy shop.  They decided to start their business in Mlolongo because it is a very fast-growing town.  The couple rented two houses to host the clinic and hospital.  The business continues to grow as many patients seek their services.  The town is located along the only highway connecting Mombasa and Nairobi where many medical emergencies occur.  Also, Sera is able to perform labor deliveries, sending any complicated cases to Kenyatta Hospital in Nairobi.

The clinic and pharmacy have saved so many lives that Sera cannot recall the number and she wants to continue with this trend for many years to come.  She wants to add more stock of drugs to her clinic and pharmacy in order to cope with the increasing demand for medicine.  She, therefore, is requesting a loan of $1,175.  With this loan, Sera will be able to purchase drugs and supplies like syrups, tablets, injectables, and bandages.  This will greatly improve the services she is providing, save lives, and also increase her income.  

The repayment period is 10 months.

loans.use: To purchases an assortment of drugs including syrups, tablets and injectables

loans.name: Vicencia's Group

texts.en:
Vicencia K. has a beauty salon. With a loan, Vicencia wishes to buy hair oils for her shop.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Hanjar

texts.en: Hanjar, 39, is the mother of 5 children. Every day she prepares all ingredients to make coconut rice, then sells them from morning untill noon, earning $4 a day. Her husband, A., is in steel trading and earns $20 a day. She is asking for a loan of $100 to expand her business, and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Leticia

texts.es:
Señora Leticia R. Solano is 63 years old. She studied only until the third grade of primary school. She has six children but only one still depends on her. She lives in Poblado Menor "Cuyuchugo" of the district of Usquil in La Libertad, Perú

Ever since she became independent, Señora Leticia searched for a way to advance herself. She began selling fruits throughout different parts of the nearby mountains. Little by little she offered a greater variety of fruits and made a little bit of capital. In this way she was able to begin another business in selling clothes. This business she has kept to this day. On a simple sewing machine she makes aprons, skirts, and vests for selling on foot throughout Otuzco.

She is a member of the communal bank "San Juan de Miraflores" through which she received her first loan of 300 Soles. She used this money to buy fabrics.

With the loan of 900 Soles, which she will pay back in four months, she will buy fabrics, threads, and zippers for the manufacture of aprons and vests.

Señora Leticia dreams of growing her business and having a greater variety of merchandise to offer her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Leticia R. Solano tiene 63 años de edad, estudió sólo hasta el tercer grado de primaria. Tiene 6 hijos pero solo uno depende de ella. Vive en el Poblado Menor “Cuyuchugo” del Distrito de Usquil de la Provincia de Otuzco del Departamento de La Libertad - Perú

Desde que se independizó la señora Leticia buscó la manera de salir adelante. Se inició vendiendo frutas por diferentes partes de la sierra cercanas a su caserío; poco a poco fue teniendo mayor variedad de frutas, hizo un pequeño capital y de esa manera pudo emprender otro negocio que es la venta de ropa, este negocio lo mantiene hasta la fecha. En una sencilla máquina de cocer confecciona mandiles, faldas, vestidos para luego venderlos en condición de ambulante por toda la provincia de Otuzco.

Pertenece al Banco Comunal “San Juan de Miraflores” en el cual recibió su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 , este dinero lo empleo en comprar telas.

Con el préstamo de S/900.00 que cancelará en 4 meses comprará telas, hilos y cierres para la confección de mandiles y vestidos.

Sueña con ampliar su negocio y tener variedad de mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy fabric, threads, and zippers for the manufacture of articles of clothing.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria O. is 52 years old, married and has 8 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. Victoria sells oranges and has been in business since 1995. She asks for a loan of $450 to purchase more oranges for sale.

loans.use: To buy more oranges for sale.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married and has a 7 year old child. She started selling clothes in 2007. She works from 7am to 7pm every day and earns a monthly profit of about $250.

Lydia plans to use this loan to buy more clothes to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jorge Ricardo

texts.es:
Jorge is married and works as a plumber and electrician. He currently works for a company, but he also provides these same services during his spare time. These two jobs have allowed him to help his family get ahead in life.

He currently needs a loan of $400.00 USD, which he will repay in 6 months, in order to upgrade his equipment, as well as purchase a bigger oxygen tank so that he can carry out his tasks.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Jorge esta casado, pero por su tipo de trabajo solamente lo realiza el personalmente, ya que ofrece servicio de plomeria y electricidad, actualmente labora en una empresa, pero en sus tiempos libres hace este tipo de trabajos. Combinando estas actividades ha podido sacar adelante a su familia.

Actualmente, requiere un prestamo por US $ 400 que pagara en 6 meses para modernizar el equipo de corte con el que contaba, ademas de comprar un tanque de oxigeno mas grande, para realizar sus trabajos.

loans.use: Purchase work tools

loans.name: Sandra Maria

texts.es:
Sandra H. works in a grocery store in Somotllo in the city of Chinandega, where she comes from. Seven years ago she decided to invest in some stock to sell. As they started to sell bit by bit, she decided to buy more which led to her setting up her grocery store from home.

Her two children are very proud of her as she is now able to give them everything they need to study and to survive.
