Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 15.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar matrial  de construção (cimento, ferro, pedra, areia, e outros ) para continuar a construir a sua casa.
Sonha em concluir a sua obra, mobiliar e iniciar outra obra para aluguer e para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Augusto was born in the Namaacha district in the Maputo province in southern Mozambique.  He is married and has two children, ages 4 and 12.  The older child attends school.  Augusto attended school through the 8th grade but dropped out due to financial circumstances.  He lives in his own home with his family and does not support anyone else.  

He left Namaacha for Maputo to look for work.  He has worked for 10 years as a driver for a private company and has a monthly salary of 8.000.00mt which he uses to cover household expenses and for savings in his bank account. 

Augusto has never had a loan with other banks.  He learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is his first loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 15.000.00mt, which he will use to purchase construction materials (cement, iron, stones, sand, etc.) to continue construction on his home.  He dreams of completing his home, furnishing it, and building another one to rent.  He plans to request more loans from Hluvuku for this purpose.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials ( cement, iron, stones, sand, etc.).

loans.name: Joaquín Bernardo

texts.es:
Desde hace 13 años, Joaquín es artesano, trabaja todos los días de la semana con la ilusión de ver crecer su negocio y día a día ir mejorando su técnica y por ende la calidad de los productos que fabrica, esta labor que aprendió empíricamente y que actualmente sueña con poder generar muchos empleos y ayudarle a la gente de su comunidad a salir adelante gracias a su microempresa, pero para esto es conciente que necesita producir mas artesanías, conseguir mas cliente y tener mas capacidad en su taller para ir creciendo poco a poco.

Es por esta razón que hoy en día Joaquín solicita un crédito que le permita comprar en grandes cantidades materia prima como lo es Yeso, cemento, moldes, hierro, resina, entre otros; ya que así podrá ampliar su producción y proporcionalmente las utilidades, lo que le ayudará a mejorar poco a poco su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Joaquín has made handcrafts since he was 13, and works hard every day to improve his technique and grow his business; he dreams one day to employ others and help his community through his micro-business.  He knows he has to work hard, attract clientele and increase the productiivity of his workshop.  For this reason, Joaquín now seeks a credit to buy craft materials such as molds, metal, resin, cement and other products; he is confident that this will increase his production of crafts and help him achieve a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy craft materials

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 58 years old. She is a widow with eight children. She has been doing a retail business for the past seven years with a monthly income of KES 8,000, which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for her fifth loan from KADET after repaying the previous loans successfully. She will use the loan to buy cereals, maize meal and tomatoes to add to her business. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, she plans to expand her business. Her hope is to open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy cereals, maize meal and tomatoes to add to her business.

loans.name: Corina Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Corina se dedica al negocio de venta de comida, con muchos años en las ventas, pues ha sido su medio para apoyar a su familia, y su esposo quien ya se jubilo hoy en dia.
Cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos quienes trabajan,  y ahora con financiamiento que Afodenic ha dado, ha logrado aumentar las ventas y mejorar el menu de sus platillos.
Años anteriores lograron la construccion de su vivienda, toda de concreto, lo que desea hacer es poner  ventanas y puerta de madera,  ya que solo las tiene con verjas. Siendo de prioridad para mejor seguridad de su familia. siendo posible a traves del prestamo, con cuotas accesibles.
texts.en:
Señora Corina works in a business selling food.  She has been making sales for many years, as it has been a means to help her family and her husband, who is is currently retired.

She counts on the help of her children who are working, and now with the loan that Afodenic has given her, she has been able to increase her sales and improve her menu of dishes.

In previous years they were able to build their home, which is made of concrete throughout.  What she would like to do is put in windows and a wooden door, as they only have gates.  

She feels that her priority is better security for her family, and feels this is possible through the loan, with affordable repayments.

loans.use: to buy doors and windows as she currently only has gates, and her big priority is the security of her family.

loans.name: Poulyne

texts.en:
Poulyne is 34 years old, married to Peterson, and blessed with one child aged 10. She has been in the cosmetics business for the last two years, making a monthly profit of 10,000 KES. She has been loaned 80,000 KES, which she plans to use to stock beauty products, creams, lotions, etc.
With the anticipated profits, she plans to expand her business and educate her child to higher levels of education. In the near future, she hopes to venture into the business of supplying electricity poles to the Kenya Power and Lighting Company.

loans.use: to purchase stock such as beauty products, creams, lotions, etc.

loans.name: Cristina Lizeth

texts.es:
Cristina es una joven madre soltera nacida en la ciudad de Ibarra en la provincia de "Imbabura". Tiene una hija de 3 años, actualmente vive en su lugar de nacimiento. Ibarra es una ciudad de la sierra del Ecuador ubicada al norte del país. Su clima es cálido ya que se encuentra en uno de los valles de la provincia. Conocida como "la ciudad blanca a la que siempre se vuelve" es cuna de las más grandes estrellas del fútbol soccer ecuatoriano.

Trabaja medio tiempo en una tienda de venta de artículos plásticos y el resto del día vende ropa por catálogo, en ninguna de las actividades recibe ayuda. Ella desea un préstamo para comprar mercadería para ofertar a sus clientes por esta razón ella se acercó a Fundación Alternativa. La inversión específicamente la hará en ropa. Tiene la esperanza que con esta inversión mejoren sus ingresos.

Esta joven mujer es amante de la música y de la lectura, también ama los deportes. Su gran obstáculo ha sido no poder continuar con los estudios universitarios y ese es su mayor anhelo. Ella espera mejorar su calidad de vida con su pequeño crédito.
texts.en:
Cristina is a young single mother who was born in the city of Ibarra in Imbabura Province. She has a three-year-old daughter and currently lives in her hometown. Ibarra is a city located in the mountains of northern Ecuador. The climate is cold since the city is located in one of the valleys in the province. Ibarra is known as “the white city that always returns” and is the birthplace of the most famous Ecuadorian soccer stars.

Cristina works part-time at a store that sell plastic goods and the rest of her day is spent selling clothes through catalogs. She does not receive help with any of her business activities. Cristina wants a loan so that she can buy merchandise to offer to her customers. For this reason, she approached Fundación Alternativa. This investment will be used specifically to buy clothing. She hopes that this investment will improve her income.

This young woman loves music and reading. She is also a sports fan. Her greatest obstacle has been not being able to continue her university studies, which is her greatest wish. Cristina hopes to improve her quality of life with this small loan.

loans.use: to purchase clothing.

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es: Ángeles es una señora trabajadora y responsable, tiene 35 años edad es madre soltera y tiene dos niños que dependen de ella, nos platica que a partir que se separo de su esposo ella lleva las riendas de su casa y que tiene que trabajar muy duro para sacar adelante a sus hijos  ya que van a la escuela y son gastos muy pesados para una mujer sola. Dice que através de los créditos que le han hecho a salido adelante con sus hijos y eso la tiene muy contenta por que poco a poco va mejorando la calidad de vida de su familia. Ella se dedica a vender productos por catalogo como cosméticos, perfumería, artículos para el hogar, zapatos etc. dice que pedirá un crédito para seguir invirtiendo en sus artículos que vende ya que ahorita tiene varios pedidos que le han hecho sus clientas pero debido a que no ha podido tener el capital junto no ha podido surtir ya que vende sus productos a pagos a sus clientas. La meta que tiene Ángeles es rentar un local y poner un distribuidor autorizado para así poder estar mas al pendiente de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Ángeles is a hard-working and responsible woman. She is 35, and a single mother with two small children who depend on her. She tells us that from the time she separated from her husband, she has taken the reins of the household.  She has had to work very hard to bring up her children, as they go to school, and the expenses are very onerous for a woman on her own.

She says that through the loans she has been granted, she and her children have made progress, and that has made her very happy; because she is gradually improving her family's quality of life. She sells products by catalogue, such as cosmetics, perfume, articles for the home, shoes, etc. 

She is asking for the loan in order to continue buying the articles that she sells, since right now she has several orders that her customers have placed with her, that she hasn't been able to fill, due to not having sufficient working capital. This is because she sells her products to her customers on an instalment payment basis.  

Ángeles has the goal of renting a shop and establishing herself as an authorized distributor, so that she can devote more time to her children.

loans.use: To sell cosmetics and shoes by catalogue.

loans.name: Kadiamor Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 08 MAI 2001. Il  est  constitué de 07 femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le commerce. 

Madame Aida qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 54 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge une belle fille.

Elle s’active dans la vente de poissons. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, qu'elle pratique depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
The Kadiamor solidarity group was created on the 8th of May, 2001. It is made up of 7 women who are all retailers and all live in the same area.

Aida, on the right of the picture with her hand raised, is the group's leader. She is 54 years old, married and the mother of 6 children. She is also raising one stepchild.

Aida is an experienced fish seller who has been active in this area for several years. This loan will increase her working capital and allow her to restock and develop her business activities. She will use the profits from her business to improve her family's standard of living - by buying food and clothing, paying medical expenses, etc. - and to increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy fish for resale.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is a 26-year-old married man and a father of two children between 3 and 4 years old. He lives in his own permanent residential house at Hoima in Western Uganda. 

Musa has been running a butchery shop for the past seven years. He started with a small amount of capital but now it has now grown considerably. He says he has been able to achieve this with the help of credit from Hofokam. 

He faces a challenge of price fluctuations for goats and cows. Musa is requesting a loan to buy cows and goats for sale at his butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy cows and goats for sale at his butcher shop.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 43 years old and lives in Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has 1 child. 

To earn a living, Jennifer has a business selling different meats. She earns about PHP 5,000 each month doing this type of work. Jennifer has requested a loan to purchase spices and meat.

Jennifer has been a member of PMPC for 7 years.  In the future, Jennifer would like to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spices and meat.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is a married woman with 4 children. The oldest child is 23 years old. Luzviminda provides boat-ride services from the mainland of Talibon to nearby islands. She has had her business for quite some time now. Luzviminda earns 10000 PHP per month with her business. She works hard to improve her business and send her children to school.

Luzviminda has requested a loan to repair her passenger boat and to purchase a new one. Luzviminda hopes for her business to grow more.

loans.use: to repair her passenger boat and purchase a new one

loans.name: Hellen Kinya

texts.en: Hellen Kinya, age 46, is married and has five children ranging from 14 to 27 years. She has run a grocery store in the last 15 years. The business is faced with the problem of increased cost of goods. She will be using the loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock to the grocery store. In the future, Hellen wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To add stock to the grocery store.

loans.name: Maikeronisia

texts.en:
Maikeronisia is 43 years old and married with 6 children.  She owns & operates a business venture planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has 3 years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2006, Maikeronisia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Maikeronisia's 5th loan with SPBD.

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Marifat

texts.ru: Марифат женщина 51 года, замужем имеет двоих детей. Одна дочь и старший сын, который на заработках в России. Муж не работает, т.к инвалид второй группы, занимается домашними мужскими делами. Сын присылая деньги помогает жить родителям. Сама Марифат сидит на рынке и продаёт нижнее женское бельё и колготки.Она хочет на полученный кредит закупить партию зимних колгот и бриджей, которые пользуются большим спросом у населения на рынке. Она за четырёхлетний период кредитования ни разу не нарушала условия организации и кредит использует целенаправлено.
texts.en: Marifat is 51 year-old woman, married and has two children.  She has one daughter and an older son, who is now in Russia for work.  Her husband does not work because he is a disabled person of a second group, and takes care of men's home work.  Their son helps the parents by sending money home.  Marifat works at a market and sells women's undergarments and stockings.  She wants to use this loan to purchase an inventory of winter stockings and breeches, which are in high demand among the residents at the market.  Over her four years of obtaining financing, Marifat has not once violated the terms of the organization and has used her loans purposefully.

loans.use: to purchase an inventory of winter clothing

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a hardworking mother who aims to become successful someday. She is 52 years old and has four adult-age children. She is engaged in a vegetable vending business to help her husband in generating income. Despite the hardship of living, they continued to work and strive until they educated all their children. They are proud to say that it is their biggest accomplishment in life. 

In relevance to this, they planned to continue and improve the business to earn and save more income to satisfy their necessities and save for their future. To work out their plan, Teresita is requesting additional capital of P18,000 to buy more stock of vegetables, like cabbages, tomatoes, eggplants, beans and potatoes to sell. She believes that when she works harder, she will improve the business and make it a viable source of income in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of vegetables, like cabbages, tomatoes, eggplants, beans and potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Blanca Lidia

texts.es:
Blanca, nuevamente solicita un préstamo el cual le ayudara aumentar en sus ganancias y comprar pan dulce, pan francés y llevarlos a los hogares de sus clientes de esa forma lograra que sus productos se vendan.
Blanca considera que los prestamos anteriores le ayudaron porque siempre tiene la mercadería necesaria y su familia vive mejor que antes.
texts.en: Blanca is again requesting a loan which will help her expand her earnings and purchase sweet bread and french bread and to take them to the homes of her customers, by which she will ensure her products are sold. Blanca considers that her previous loan helped her because she always has the necessary merchandise and her family lives better than before.

loans.use: to purchase sweet bread and french bread.

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia is 35 years old and lives in Taboc Norte, Oroquieta City. She is married and has two children.
 
Nemia has a fish vending business and earns approximately PHP 5,000 each month doing this work. 

She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more fish to sell.
 
Nemia has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Nemia hopes to purchase a fishing boat.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Estrellas De Llanquichapi Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ESTRELLITAS DE LLANQUICHAPI”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Margarita es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de pan de laja, venta de pescado, venta de cerveza, venta de carne, venta de verduras.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Margarita es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de pescado; cuenta que este negocio lo implemento por recomendación de su padre quien le enseño este negocio desde niña, cuando tuvo su primer hijo decide implementar su negocio independientemente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de red de pesca) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la Ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo implementará en su espacio de pesca. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es soltera y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The Estrellitas de Llanquichapi communal bank will begin its first cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Copacabana regional hub.  It is made up of eight members and is lead by a Board of Directors, of which Señora Margarita is president.  The businesses that the communal bank members carry out are varied.  Among them are: flatbread sales, beer sales, meat sales, and vegetables sales.

The loan that they are taking out will benefit these small-time microentrepreneurs, of which Señora Margarita is one.  She says that this is her first time with Pro Mujer.  She joined due to an invitation from a promoter of the organization who went to visit her in her home.  She currently has a business selling fish.  She says that she began this business on the advice of her father, who taught her the trade from the time she was a girl.  When she had her first child she decided to start her own business.

The loan that she is taking out now is to increase her capital for the purchase of a fishing net which she will get from the wholesale suppliers in the city of La Paz.  Later she will use it in her fishing business.  This type of work lets her generate income to support her home as well as possible, because she is single and has five children.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training sessions the organization offers.

loans.use: to buy a fish net.

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Lily. She is thirty eight years old, married and a mother of seven children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2015 and has benefited from enterprise development and financial management training.
She does potatoes farming as her main economic activity. She is borrowing from Kiva to buy fertilizer so that she can increase her potatoes yields. She hopes she’ll earn more income that will enable her provide food for her family.
She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer hence increased potatoes production and income to provide food for her family.

loans.name: Somoul

texts.en:
I. Somoul is living with her grown son in a quickly built and precarious shelter in a new village around 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They moved in two weeks ago and have felt a critical need for housing improvement since their arrival. I. Somoul herself requested a $300 loan but she trusts her son to manage everything related to the works. He explained us he is going to buy for $250 of materials such as sand, cement, wood and zinc and hire two people from the community for 100,000 Riel ($25) for 1 week. He truly believes the works can be completed one single week after receiving the money from CREDIT.

I. Somoul is concerned about repaying her loan. She is self-employed and sells fruits and vegetable in a Market in Phnom Penh. She gets up early morning with her son and together they go to buy their fruits and vegetables at 4 am. She usually finishes at 5pm. She can make 20,000 Riel ($5) profit every day, while her son is making 10,000 Riel from taxi fares.

loans.use: Improving the house

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz is an Internally Displaced Person ( IDP ) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli. He settled with his family in Sumgait city.

He began his business 6 years ago, when he was 14 years old. In the beginning of his business he sold retail. Having borrowed the loan amount of $300 from Normicro he rented a grocery store. The second time he borrowed $400, he bought 90 pair of shoes and expanded his business. Parviz has rented a shoe store and he needs a loan of $800 to open his own shoe shop and to increase the range of shoes.

loans.use: To open his own shoe shop and to increase range of shoes

loans.name: Eseese

texts.en: Eseese is 29-years old.  She has seven children and she lives in the small village of Sataoa.  She is very happy about her small fishing business that she runs with her husband.  Eseese’s husband does most of the fishing in the daytime when the tide is low.  Eseese is responsible for selling the fish; she sells fish in front of their house under the shade of a large tree.  Many people pass by, and on a good day, Eseese is able to bring in about ST 200 (USD 80).  This is the sole income source for her and her large family.  An initial loan from SPBD helped her purchase time-saving equipment which has improved their fishing yield, and she is anxious to secure more loan funds to invest further in her business.

loans.use: Purchase fishing nets, spears and baskets

texts.en: Mrs. C. is 31 yrs old, and her husband is 32. They have two children, ages 8 and 12, both at school. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper center of Vietnam. Mrs. C. sells pork at the local market. She buys pigs from farmers and sells the meat. Before joining TYM she borrowed money from local lenders at very high rates. Since joining TYM she has to pay less interest, and her extra profit is mainly used for the education of her children.

loans.use: She wants to do some maintenance on her house

loans.name: Fatmata Tity

texts.en: Fatmata Tity C. is forty-five years old.  She is married with four children. She produces and also buys and sells palm oil to traders in Freetown. She owns a store in her residence in Fadugu village.  Before her previous loan, Fatmata worked as a middle person who buys the products from the producers and sells them to traders from Freetown and Makeni.  Realizing a small profit, Fatmata started selling the palm oil directly to retailers in Freetown and Makeni. She said by selling to retailers directly, she makes double the profit.  She is requesting another loan to expand her business.  This will improve the status of her family, she added.

loans.use: Expansion of palm oil production and wholesale business.

loans.name: Muhaie

texts.ru:
Muhaie is 35 years old, she is married and has 3 sons. Muhaie is one of the first clients of MicroInvest. Back then she sold children’s clothing and footwear. The profits from that business were not large enough and she decided to go to Russia to earn money. She returned after one year and again started a business, this time selling food. She also returned to borrowing from MicroInvest. Muhaie’s eldest son helps her in her trade. The newly restored business brings her normal profits for supporting her family.

Muhaie will use the new loan to further expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мухайе 35 лет, она замужем, имеет 3 сыновей. Мухайе является одной из первых клиенток Микроинвест. Тогда она продавала детскую одежду и обувь. Прибыли от бизнеса было недостаточно и она решила выехать на заработки в Россию. Через год она вернулась и опять занялась бизнесом и перешла на торговлю продуктами питания. Также она возобновила получение займов в Микроинвест. В торговле ей помогает ее старший сын. Вновь налаженный бизнес приносит ей нормальную прибыль для содержания семьи. Новый займ она потратит на дальнейшее его расширение.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose S. is 28-years old. She is one of the active fashion designers in her area and because of that she has numerous customers. She started her business in 1998. She is from Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of US$325 to enable her buy more cloth and tailoring supplies to make clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cloth and tailoring material

loans.name: Ketty's Group

texts.en:
Ketty K. wants to buy more products for her grocery business so that she meets the demands of her customers, earns more revenue, and earns more profits.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To enlarge her business

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti A., 23, mother of a child aged 1, has a food stall where she sells snacks, candies, etc., earning $10 a day. Her husband, Baiti Ali, sells waste materials and earns $3 a day. She is a member of MBK and asks for a loan of $75 to fill her stall with more goods. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Buy more goods

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mrs. Yim C. is 44 years old and works as a fish seller at Takmoa market in the Takmoa District of the Kandal province. She has two children who are both in school. Her husband, Mr. Nhoem Sarith, is 50 years old and works as a vegetable farmer. To earn a living for their family, Yim and her husband work very hard everyday. Because of their business, their children can now continue to study.

Yim needs a loan of $1000.00 to buy a new motorcycle to transport fish and vegetables to the market more efficiently. She has proven to be a reliable client of HKL in the past. And she thanks HKL for their support and promises to be accurate in her loan payment.

Her husband is pictured in the photo because she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to transport fish and vegetables to the market

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude is the mother of three young boys.    She has been operating a small stand in a crowded alley of central Kumasi for five years.  Someday, she hopes to have a permanent shop.  This is her second loan with Sinapi Aba Trust.  With the first loan, she has seen an improvement in her standard of living.  

With this second loan, Gertrude wants to increase the variety of products she sells.  By increasing her inventory, she hopes to increase her sales and begin setting aside more money to help with her children's educational expenses.   She also has yet to register with Ghana's National Health Insurance Scheme and plans to use some of her increase income to register.  

Gertrude is the member of the trust group Pillar of God.  The trust group uses peer pressure as a form of social collateral to ensure each member repays.  

Gertrude is pictured on the right.  On the left is her loan officer, Annastasia.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of women's undergarments

loans.name: Nasra

texts.en:
Nasra is 24 years old, married, and has a 5 year old child. Nasra owns a small food shop, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of $190 from her sales.

Nasra has applied for this loan so that she can buy more products (such as soda, salt, sugar and juice) for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more items (e.g. soda, salt, soap, sugar and juice) to sell

loans.name: Masitula

texts.en:
Masitula N. owns a small boutique in Najjembe trading centre that sells new clothes for men, women and children. She has had her shop for one year and she has been a member of the Mabira development group for 10 years. In the shop, she is helped by her sister especially during the holidays and she pays her school fees as a reward. She is proud of her business and would like to keep it and restock it to the brim. She is a married woman with three children, all in school, and she takes care of three of her in-laws. Her husband works as a manager in a company.

Masitula needs a loan to help with buying more clothes for her boutique.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for men, women and children for her boutique.

loans.name: Kifayatou

texts.fr:
Born December 15, 1977 Kitayatou A. is married to Raimou Abogourin. She is the mother of two, the oldest attends elementary school and is 8 years old while the other is still a baby, only one year old. She sells health products for newborns and babies such as cotton swabs, baby powder, ointments and diverse toothpastes. Mrs. Kitayatou A. often purchases her stock in Nigeria as well as in Togo and for the moment is in Benin. She will sell her items in the international market Dantokpa in Benin.

Translated from French into English by Kiva Volunteer translator, Kristin Connor.

Née le 15 Décembre 1977 à A. Kifayatou est mariée à monsieur ABOGOURIN Raïmou. Elle est mère de deux enfants dont l’aîné qui est au CE1 à 8 ans et le second, encore bébé, a un 1 an d'âge. Elle vend des produits de soins corporelles pour les nouveaux nés tels que les dessous (couches) pour bébé, les cotons tige, de la poudre de beauté, des pommades et diverses sortes de pâtes dentifrices. Dame A. Kifayatou s’approvisionne souvent au Nigeria et au Togo puis par moment au Bénin. Elle expose ses articles au marché international DANTOKPA de Cotonou au Bénin.

loans.use: To purchase four cartons of baby clothes, 10 boxes of baby powder, 20 ointments and different toothpastes.

loans.name: Theam

texts.en: Mrs. Theam R. lives in Bampong Phchoek Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a basketmaker and her husband, Mr. Saneth Hoeurg, is a farmer and pig breeder. Even though Mrs. Theam R. and her husband have different business activities, they still cannot support the family well. Therefore, Mrs. Theam R. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to sell later at a better price. Mrs. Theam R. is 34 and the mother of six children, four of whom are attending school while the others are too young to work or study. Previously, Mrs. Theam R. had obtained a loan from AMK to buy piglets, and she has fully paid it back. She and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Tat

texts.en:
Mrs. Tat L. is a pig and poultry breeder in Trea Tbong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a 56-year-old widow without any children. She is a hard-working woman who supports herself.

Because her business is going well, Mrs. L. wants to expand it. So she is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding so she can earn more and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: Buy more piglets for breeding to earn more and improve living conditions

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo C. lives in Roluos Village in Takeo Province. She owns a small grocery store in the local village and she is also a farmer. In her plantation, she now face a small problem because the soil in her field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Keo C. decided to ask a loan to buy fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Khoem Sovann, is a teacher who can make $50 per month. Mrs. Keo C. is 28 years old and the mother of two children, both of whom are too young to go to school. Mrs. Keo C.'s family is shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Merita

texts.es:
La señora Merita pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Libertad” y vive en la región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Bellavista, Centro Poblado Menor de La Libertad. Se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de carnes, sobre todo de res, pollo y cerdo y su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa, lugar donde espera a sus clientes para atenderles con mucha amabilidad. Decidió emprender este negocio porque en su localidad no hay un mercado y un lugar especifico donde encontrar carnes.

Con este crédito de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará cerdos, ganados y pollos vivos para luego sacrificarlos y venderlos por kilos a sus clientes que son muy exigentes.

La señora Merita tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo y con su hijo. Ella y su esposo trabajan duro para salir adelante y en un futuro quiere arreglar su local para dar prestigio a su negocio, para que resalte y que sea muy concurrido en la comunidad.
texts.en:
Merita belongs to the La Libertad community bank and lives in the small town of La Libertad, in the Bellavista district of San Martín. She specializes in the sale of all sorts of meat, especially beef, chicken and pork. Her shop is located in her home, where she hopes her customers are met with a cordial atmosphere. Merita decided to start this business because there was no market or place where meat was sold in her area. With this six-month loan of $350 (1,000 nuevos soles), she will buy live pigs, steers and chicken to later butcher and sell by the kilo to her many customers. Merita is 31 years old, and lives with her husband and child. She and her husband are working hard to get ahead, and in the future she wants to refurbish her business premises to give her shop a good reputation, so it is competitive and stands out in the community.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pigs, steers and chickens

loans.name: Giuliana

texts.es: Giuliana tiene 20 años, es soltera y vive en casa de sus padres. Su juventud no la detuvo para emprender su propio negocio y sacarlo adelante, su arduo trabajo de 9 años está arrojando buenos resultados. Giuliana empezó apoyando en el negocio de sus padres, pero éstos ya cansados y viendo en su hija todas las ganas de sacarlo adelante, decidieron dejarle el negocio a ella, es así que desde entonces Giuliana se encarga de su negocio de venta de calzado. Lo más difícil para ella, es tener que realizar viajes a las ciudades de Arequipa y Tacna a comprar la mercadería. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero comprará una mayor cantidad de zapatos para poder vender en su tienda.
texts.en:
Giuliana is 20 years old, single, and lives with her parents. Her youth did not stop her from starting her own business and making it get ahead, and her hard work of nine years is yielding good results. Giuliana started by helping out in her parents’ business, however, they were tired and after seeing all the eagerness she had to progress they decided to give her the business. In this manner, Giuliana became in charge of their enterprise selling footwear. The most difficult part for her is the need to travel to the cities of Arequipa and Tacna to purchase her merchandise. This is the first loan she requests with MFP. With the funds, she will buy a greater quantity of shoes to sell in her store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a greater quantity of shoes to sell in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
Eight people who live in the Pau Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia, have a group loan. The members of the group will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Chheang R. was selected by the members as the village bank president. She owns a small grocery store in the local market. Her business is going well, and she wants to expand it. So she is requesting a loan to buy more grocery products and enlarge the inventory. She hopes to increase her income and thus provide better living conditions for her family. Mrs. Chheang R. is a 55-year-old widow with two children who are farmers.

loans.use: Buy more grocery products for larger inventory in the store

loans.name: Elisa Del Carmen

texts.en:
Elisa D. Carmen T. D. A. is a forty-four year old mother of three.  She lives in Pucallpa– the capital city of the Ucayali region in Peru’s Amazon River basin.  Elisa’s business is a flower shop that she runs on Salaverry Street.  She sells flowers, teddy bears, decorative adornments and statuettes.  She started this business just four months ago with her relative.  She is pictured above in front of her shop's new sign.

Elisa is a member of the Talented Women communal bank and has taken out loans through Manuela Ramos and Kiva for one year.  Elisa is currently requesting 1,200 Nuevo Soles to help fund the purchase of more flowers, gifts, and decorations to stock her shop.  Elisa will repay her loan in four monthly installments.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more flowers, gifts, and decorations to stock her shop

loans.name: Genaro

texts.es:
El señor Genaro vive en casa de sus padres con su esposa e hijos en la Av. Buenos aires de la zona Las Nieves de la ciudad de La Paz; la actividad que tiene es la confección de ternos, el trabaja directamente con su esposa y dos personas que son las que se encargan de coser ya que Genaro corta la tela.  La esposa viaja a Desaguadero (ciudad en la frontera con Perú), lugar donde tiene su puesto  de venta.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar material (telas, forros, botones, hilo) y de esta manera continuar e incluso mejorar su volumen de producción  para ofrecer a sus clientes.

Su antecedente con Impro se remontan al año 2001, con un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Señor Genaro lives in his parents' home with his wife and children, on Buenos Aires Avenue, Las Nieves zone, in the city of La Paz. His business is tailoring men's suits, working with his wife and two other persons charged with the sewing while Genaro cuts the fabric. His wife travels to Desaguadero (a city on the Peru frontier), where he has his sales location. The credit he is requesting is for the purchase of materials (fabric, linings, buttons, thread) in order to continue and increase his volume of production to offer to his clients. His record with Impro goes back to 2001, with an excellent history of repayment, giving him access to this new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, linings, buttons, and thread for tailoring men's suits in his shop

loans.name: Olinda

texts.es: Olinda tiene 40 años, vive  con su esposo y sus 7 hijos en su propia casa. Se dedica a la fabricación de sogas desde hace 12 años, empezó primero vendiendo al por menor las sogas ya fabricadas, luego tuvo la oportunidad de trabajar en una fabrica de sogas, lo que la favoreció, ya que aprendió rápidamente y decidió fabricar ella misma las sogas y lo que produce lo reparte al por mayor en distintas ciudades. Por la calidad de la producción,  ha notado que ha mejorado bastante sus ventas y produce en mayor cantidad, sus hijos son los que la ayudan a fabricar. El gran sueño de Olinda es la de tener una fábrica a gran escala e innovar en sus productos. Es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, está decidida a continuar en el trabajo que realiza en su banco comunal y en las reuniones que se dan, ya que es un persona de confianza por haber demostrado puntualidad en sus pagos. El dinero que ahora solicita es para la compra de fardos de plástico y retazos de tela que son el material básico para la fabricación de sus  sogas, cada fardo tiene un precio aproximado de 300 soles y comprará 10 fardos.
texts.en:
Olinda is 40 years old and lives with her husband and seven children in her own home. For twelve years she has made ropes. She began by selling manufactured ropes, but later had the opportunity to work in a rope factory. She was a quick learner and found that the work really suited her, so she decided to start her own business manufacturing ropes and now sells them wholesale in various cities. Because her ropes are of higher quality, she has noticed an increase in sales, and, with her children's help, she is able to produce rope in greater quantities. Olinda's big dream is to have a large-scale factory and be able to create innovative products.

This is Olinda's third loan from Kiva's partner Microfinanzas PRISMA, and she is committed to continuing her work with the bank, including attending their meetings. Olinda is a trustworthy person and has been very punctual in her repayments.

She will invest the money from this loan in the purchase of bundles of plastic and fabric remnants, which are the raw materials from which she produces her ropes. Each bundle costs approximately 300 Peruvian nuevos soles (US $92.50) and she will buy ten bundles.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials to make ropes

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Marry has been a banana seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for 12 years. She belongs to Donbosco group loan (Group code 2026).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $215. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.
 
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bananas to sell and improve her business. She hopes that with this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, get more food for her family, save money for the future, and pay school fees for her children.  

Marry is married and has five children aged 27, 21, 19, 15 and 11.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Chanthoen

texts.en:
Mrs Chanthoen C. lives in Sdau Kanlaeng village in Kandal province, Cambodia. She is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study.

Chanthoen C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates both rice and vegetables. However, she does not have enough resources to grow the vegetables and, in order to deal with this problem, she has asked for a loan to buy vegetable seed, fertilizer, and gasoline to pump water to the field. Her husband, Mr Suon Samnang (shown on the left of the photo), is a fisherman and also helps his wife in her work.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed, fertilizer, and gasoline to pump water to the field

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en: N. Jane is the leader of Akuwa Olukaba group in Jinja. She has a business of a retail shop that she has owned for 10 years. In the shop, Jane sells sugar, salt, oils, Vaseline, groundnuts, rice etc and she is happy that her shop has expended ever since she started getting loans. She is a mother of 7 children of which 4 are in school and she works hard to ensure that their school fees is paid on time. Jane needs a new loan that will help her restock her shop with more quantities of the goods she sells in the shop. Jane is also a farmer and the food she grows helps her save on the money she would have used on purchasing the same food that she grows now. She is surely grateful for the loans they get.

loans.use: To buy rice and sauce for her restaurant.

loans.name: Felicita

texts.es:
Felicita es socia del Bancomunal Fuerza y Poder.
Felicita es casada tiene 44 años, tres hijos de 23, 22 y 16 años este último está estudiando en la escuela estatal.
Felicita estudio tres años cosmetología y curso de especialización, trabajo en una peluquería de su profesora por tres años, después se independizo, alquilo un local hace dos años en el cual ella atiende,  también vende productos de belleza.    
Felicita necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de una vitrina, y de materiales para peluquería, líquidos, tintes.
Desde que está en Finca ha podido poner su negocio, es una ayuda, aprendió a compartir cuando las socias están en necesidades. 
El sueño de Felicita es tener otra peluquería en una zona más comercial.
texts.en:
Felicita is a member of the communal bank "Fuerza y Poder." 44-year-old Felicita is married and has 3 children, ages 23, 22, and 16. Her youngest is a student in the state school. Felicita studied cosmetology for 3 years. She worked in her teacher's beauty shop for 3 years and then struck out on her own. Two years ago, she rented a shop where she also sells beauty products. Felicita needs a loan of 1000 soles to purchase a glass display case and beauty supplies, including liquids and coloring. Since she has been with Finca, she has been able to start her own business. She is helpful and shares with other Finca members when they are in need. Felicita's dream is to have another beauty shop in a more commercial area.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Felicita necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de una vitrina, y de materiales para peluquería, líquidos, tintes.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
"I am lucky and blessed that I have a husband who is responsible and always looks out for the best for our children. We started tilling a 1 hectare farm. We tried to save to be able to buy another farm. However, it will cost an arm and a leg for my family to buy land since people are selling it at a high cost," says Elizabeth P., the mother of four children.
She would like to ask for a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase urea fertilizers, seeds and herbicides. The loan will truly help improve their harvest and income as well. 
Through CEVI, Mrs. P. has been able to sustain her livelihood. Now she is a loyal client of CEVI and receives not just loans but also training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase urea fertilizers, seeds and herbicides

loans.name: John

texts.en: John V. is currently in the business of selling maize at the market and is requesting a loan to open a shop. John is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew. She says demand for food is on the high side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for ten years now. Her proceeds are used to cover her children's school bills.

Augustina is a 36-year-old woman. She is married with four children who are currently in school. She lives at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana. She wants to use this loan to buy meat and rice to increase her efficiency in producing food in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income so she can help her husband provide support for her family and their education. She belongs to the village bank called Mawusi.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Las Pastoras Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha: Coidalia del Carmen Martínez, Martha Lorena M. Martínez y Mercedes Concepción Sánchez Martínez.

El grupo solidario Las Pastoras, está conformado por tres señores originarias de la ciudad de Masaya , grupo con excelente record crediticio, sus actividades son diversas.

Doña Coidalia del Carmen Martínez vende ropa en el mercado municipal, la ropa que ofrece es ropa menor como calcetines, pañuelos, etc. y además ofrece gaseosas, reposterías y otros productos. Ella trabaja todo el día y de Lunes a Domingo, este trabajo lo aprendió de su madre que a la vez vende cerca de ella. Es casada , madre de tres hijos en edades de 10, 8 y 3 años, están con ella en el mercado.Su esposo vende ambulante en el mismo mercado.

Doña Martha Lorena M. vende granos básicos, los compra al por mayor y ella vende al detalle durante el día, tiene tres hijo de 9,5 y 4 años que van a la escuela, su esposo es comerciante en el mismo mercado donde acarrea productos, le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.
Se dedica desde muy joven a su actividad comercial y ella piensa hacer crecer su negocio y así un día mejorar su casa.
Doña Mercedes Concepción es la coordinadora del grupo, ella es persona responsable con el cargo que le toco ella se dedica a la venta de comida , refrescos, enchiladas etc., esta actividad la realiza desde hace varios años, tiene clientes fijos. En el negocio le ayudan sus hijos a la elaboración de los platos, tiene tres hijos de 9,11 y 14 años, su esposo le ayuda con la alimentación de la familia.
texts.en:
Pictured left to right: Coidalia del Carmen Martínez, Martha Lorena M. Martínez, and Mercedes Concepción Sánchez Martínez. Las Pastoras Group (The Shepherds) is comprised of three women from the city of Masaya. The group has an excellent credit history, and their businesses are diverse. Coidalia del Carmen Martínez sells clothing at the city market. The type of clothing she sells is small things such as socks, scarves, etc. She also sells fizzy drinks, baked goods, and other products. She works every day, Monday through Sunday. She learned this business from her mother, who, at the time, also was a vendor near her. She is married and the mother of three children, 10, eight, and three years old, and they go with her to the market. Her husband is also a traveling vendor in the same market. Martha Lorena M. sells basic grains that she purchases wholesale. She has three children who are nine, five, and four years old and who go to school. Her husband is a vendor in the same market where she sells her products, and he helps her with household expenses. She has been in this business since she was very young, and she is thinking of growing her business so that one day she can make home improvements. Mercedes Concepción is the leader of the group. She is the person who is responsible for the loan the group has taken out. She sells food, drinks, enchiladas, etc., which is something she has been doing for several years, and she has regular customers. Her children help her with the business by making the meals. She has three children who are nine, 11, and 14 years old. Her husband helps her provide for the family.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and merchandise

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda V. is seventy years old. She is a widow and has eight grown children. To make a living, Yolanda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.  5000 PHP is enough to purchase the additional products she wants, and that is why she chose that amount. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rafiki Group

texts.en:
Wafeba is a member of the Rafiki borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 24 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.her child is aged 1 year.

Wafeba started her own  clothing business selling clothes5 years ago,she works 12 hours aday and earn monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Wafeba`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 300,000 Tanzania shillings in order to buy more clothes for sale.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Wafeba hopes to save money and expand her business.

Amina is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested the loan amount 200,000Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 25 years old and married with two children. He lives in Hebron, Palestine.

Mohammed has a poultry business where he raises birds and sells both birds and eggs. He is requesting a loan of $2,100 to purchase more birds to sell. He says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more birds to sell

loans.name: Marcia Lismey's Group

texts.es:
La señorita Marcia es soltera sin hijo, vive en casa de su madre   en la ciudad de Caacupé Barrio Santa Ana.
La señorita Marcia trabajaba como empleada domestica en casa familiar y poco a apoco fue ahorrando su dinero para emprender su propio negocio, aprovechando la ubicación privilegiada de su casa, que está frente de la plaza del barrio, donde concurre mucha gente a diarios.
El crédito que solicita es para compra de mercaderías como: azúcar, arroz, yerba, golosinas entre otros. 
Agradece mucho a la organización por la valiosa ayuda y espera cumplir bien para seguir trabajando con la  Fundación Paraguaya y kiva.
texts.en:
Señorita Marcia is single, has no children, and lives in her mother's house in the Santa Ana neighborhood of the City of Caacupé. Marcia worked as a domestic employee in a family home and little by little was saving her money in order to launch her own business, taking advantage of the privileged location of her house, which is in front of a main plaza where many people pass daily. The loan that she is requesting is for the purchase of merchandise such as: sugar, rice, yerba (an herb), candy and other items. She is very grateful to the organization for their valuable help, and hopes to perform well as she continues to work with the Paraguaya Foundation and Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase merchandise, drinks and food

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina is requesting a loan of PHP4,000 from KIVA lenders to have additional capital for her livestock business (pig raising). She is planning to purchase an added number of piglets to grow her business and also to buy a stock of feed for the livestock's food needs. She lacks the capital now thus she is hoping for lenders to give her financial assistance. The loan she is asking for will be a big help and help her business grow. She hopes that she will be given the chance to grow her business so she can provide for the education of her youngest child. She hope to give him a bright future and she believes her business will be of great help.

Avelina is now 51 years old. She lives in the rural village of Sta. Isabela Norte Ilagan, Isabela with her family. They live there simply. Their major source of income is through the farm that was formerly managed by her husband who had passed away. Four of her eldest children are already living independently. Avelina is hoping that through her requested loan, she will be able to uplift her family's current poor living condition

loans.use: Purchase more piglets

loans.name: Sona

texts.fr: Sona B. est une femme de 57 ans, elle est veuve et vit avec son petit fils. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BOUCOTTE CENTRE depuis 3 ans et demi où elle a eu 7 expériences avec le crédit. Avec son crédit elle développe une activité de vente de légumes et de poissons secs. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de subvenir à ses propres besoins et de s'occuper de son petit fils
texts.en:
Sona B. is a 57-year old woman, she is a widoww and she lives with her young son. She has been a member of the Boucotte Centre village bank for the past 3 and a half years and she has had 7 past loans. With the loan she develops her business selling vegetables and dried fish. Her revenues permit her to provide for her own needs and to take care of her little boy.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her business.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 34 years old and married with a four-year-old daughter. She has been a dressmaker for the past four years, having previously worked as a casual laborer.

Lydia is requesting a loan of Kes 20,000 to purchase a sewing machine. She describes herself as patient, focused, and determined and says that Faulu has taught her to strategize for the future.

Lydia’s dream is to live a happy life with her family and to operate a well-established company.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.es:
La socia GUMERCINDA pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es original del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

La socia tiene 51 años de edad es casada, tienes 6 hijos y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia tiene un pequeño cafetín en el Instituto “Arco Iris”, nuestra socia es una mujer cariñosa, amable y emprendedora pues con mucho anhelo abrió el cafetín a tendiendo a jóvenes entres 16 y 24 años de edad. Ya son seis años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder aumentar el capital del negocio comprando panecillos, panetones y dulces navideños.            

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
GUMERCINDA is a client of the community bank “HATUN SONCCO”. The name of the community bank comes from the Quechua language. "HATUN" means "Large" and "SONCCO" means "Heart", which translated into English means "Large heart".

Gumercinda is 51 years old, married, and has 6 children. She lives in the imperial city of Cuzco. Gumercinda has a small cafe in the "Arco Iris (Rainbow)" Institute. She is a very caring woman, friendly and enterprising, and with a great deal of eagerness she opened her cafe, serving young people between the ages of 16 and 24. She has been doing this work for 6 years, and it has gone very well, due to the determination she brings to her work. Gumercinda is requesting a loan in order to supplement her working capital to purchase bread rolls, fruit cakes and Christmas candy.

Gumercinda appreciates the opportunity offered in this way, and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital to purchase bread rolls, fruit cakes and Christmas candy.

loans.name: Fiona's Group

texts.en: M. Fiona is a hard working and devoted lady and a single mother of three children aged 18, 15 &12 years as she takes care of orphans and grandchildren. Fiona has a drug shop in Magamaga East and when she had just started her business 12 years ago. She sells over the counter medicines that are used for treatments at home. Being a professional and having enough experience has attracted more customers to her business. She hopes to expand her drug shop to start admission sessions and to educate her children and complete building her house.

loans.use: Restocking her drug shop with more medicines.

loans.name: Faalolo

texts.en:
Faalolo A. is 52 and married with 2 children (ages 29 and 37).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Faalolo has 4 years of experience in this business.  Faalolo needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2005, Faalolo joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Faalolo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Faalolo A. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15"

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Yanet Doris

texts.es: La Sra. Yanet Doris H. F. de 27 años de edad, es madre soltera con una hija menor.Tiene casa propia de material de adobe ubicada en el Caserío de San Antonio. Trabaja como obrera de campo en una empresa agroindustrial  con 2 años de experiencia. Adicionalmente recibe otros ingresos de una pensión mensual por parte del padre de su hija. Es una persona emprendedora, que gracias a su empeño logró adquirir sus bienes. Requiere el crédito para terminar de construir su vivienda. Su sueño es lograr construir toda su vivienda con el fin de alcanzar una mejor calidad de vida. Está muy agradecida por el apoyo que le podamos brindar a través de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Senora Yanet Doris H. F., 27, is a single mother with a young daughter. She has her own adobe home in the town of San Antonio. She has 2 years experience as a farm laborer in an agroindustrial business. She also receives monthly support from the father of her daughter. She is a hard-working person who has earned what she has through hard work. She needs a loan to finish the construction of her home. Her dream is to complete her home with the goal of a better quality of life. She is very thankful for the help we are able to give her through this financing.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvement

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en: Carlos, 55 years old, is a rice farmer. He is married and has ten children. Because his family is big, he doubles his efforts in farming. He makes sure to grow his rice crops healthily so he will have an abundant harvest. He wants to double his harvest so his income will also improve. He applied to CEVI and asked to borrow Php 14,000. He will use the loan to acquire farm inputs like seeds and fertilizer. Hopefully, this loan will help Carlos double his harvest.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel T. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Rachel is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Rachel owns & operates a business providing motorcycle services to local community members. Rachel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rachel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rachel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rachel is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rachel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her business

loans.name: Luzviminda's Group

texts.en: Luzviminda M. is from the town of Malibago, Echague. She is 46 years old. Luzviminda is the group leader of a 15 member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Luzviminda Malibago group. Luzviminda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a business selling specialty hand-woven products to tourists and local community members. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make woven products. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make woven products

loans.name: Matiko

texts.en:
Matiko M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at the market  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Matiko is 38 years old and is married to a driver. She has four children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: Née en 1961 à Abomey Calavi au Bénin, H. Honorine vit depuis 17 ans environs à Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Mariée à ADANHOUNDE Joachim, Honorine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Honorine vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Honorine n'a pas été à l'école. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Honorine vend des tissus de façon ambulante, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Honorine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo. Honorine a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué les remboursements. Honorine envisage augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle. C'est donc pour renforcer son capital que Honorine sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé. Honorine ambitionne plus tard ouvrir une boutique pour la commercialisation de ses tissus.
texts.en:
Born in 1961 in Abomey Calavi in Benin, Honorine H. lived her past 17 years in Cocotomey, in the Abomey Calavi commune. Married to Joachim ADANHOUNDE, she is the mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. She lives with her children and her husband. The couple jointly shares family expenses. Honorine has not attended school; for the past ten years she has been an itinerant vendor selling pieces of fabric, which allows her to meet her needs and those of her children. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and also in Lomé, Togo. Honorine has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is considering the increase of her stock supply in response to strong customer demand. She is therefore requesting a second laon from ALIDé to reinforce her working capital. Honorine’s ambition for the future is to open a shop where she can display and sell her fabrics.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 13 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Massajja A Wakawesa Margaret Group

texts.en: W. Margaret is a hardworking businesswoman of thirty-eight years who sells used clothes and has been in her business for over seven years. She is a married woman blessed with four children, all in school, and looks after two dependents who are in school too. She is using the loan to stock used clothes for sale. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate the children.

loans.use: To stock used clothes for sale

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en:
Teymur H. is a 24-year-old man who lives in the small village of Saatli. He is married and has one son.

Teymur has bred calves since 2002. His father raised cattle and he conveyed the best of his experience to Teymur. Now, Teymur has good experience of his own in raising calves.

Teymur usually purchases small calves to raise and sell them for a profitable price to the local butchers and restaurants. He applied for 1,000 AZN loan to purchase three calves and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Mitema Group

texts.en:
Meet Amina M. and the Mitema Group. Amina is 47 years old, married and has four grown children. Her fifth child died giving birth last year, and Amina also cares for her three young grand-children who are 12 years, 3 years and 10 months old.

Amina runs a business going door-to-door selling traditional African fabrics called khanga and vitenge. In the late afternoons she also sells firewood at a small stand. Amina starts work around 11am, after taking care of her grandchildren. She works until about 6 pm each day and earns a profit of about 75000 TSH ($50) per month.

This is Amina's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use it to buy additional khanga and vitenge for her fabric sales, and extra firewood for her stand. Any profit from this loan will go to support school-fees for her eldest grandchild, milk for the younger kids, and general household expenses.

Amina hopes that as her business grows she will be able to stop selling firewood and focus exclusively on fabric sales. She wants to buy a permanent shop for her business instead of selling door to door. She would also like to purchase fabrics from other countries in the region including Malawi and Zambia.

Amina is the Assistant Treasurer of the Mitema Group. The group's 17 members run a variety of businesses including selling fabrics, food, and chickens. The group's members hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, Amina is in the middle with her arm raised.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Kory Tawaco Group

texts.es:
En el Centro Focal Exaltación, se reúnen cada dos semanas la Asociación Comunal Kory Tawaco. Su presidenta es Julia R.  que tiene el negocio de tejido de chompas de lana, cuenta que inicio su negocio desde jovencita ya que disfrutaba de tejer, con el pasar del tiempo puedo convertirlo en un negocio que ahora es su principal ingreso para sustentar a su familia, ella compra su materia prima  de la Ceja y sus productos terminados los vende ofreciendo de puerta en puerta en diferentes zonas, cuando se le acumula trabajo tiene el apoyo de su hija, Julia está solicitando $us.- 400 y tiene planifido comprar lana para  estocarse.
Las demás integrantes de este grupo tienen diferentes actividades que se dedican al comercio, producción y servicio.
texts.en:
The community association 'Kory Tawaco' meet every two weeks in the community center 'Exaltación'. Their president is Julia R. who runs a business knitting woollen jumpers. She began this business when she was young because she really enjoyed knitting. As time went by she converted it into the main source of income for her family. She buys the raw material in la Ceja and sells the finished products from door to door in different areas. When the work builds up her daughter helps her. Julia is applying for $400 USD and plans to buy wool to stock up on supplies. The other members of the group are involved in different activities in the commercial, production and service industries.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland C. is from the village of  Iligan City. He is 28 years old. Roland is separated from his spouse and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Roland owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing  motorcycle services to local community members.
